author: mklement0
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Set-Location $HOME
${/:foo.txt} = 'hi, mom'
Get-Content foo.txt
````

Expected behavior
-----------------

```powershell
hi, mom
```

Actual behavior
---------------

The 2nd line causes the following error:

```
Access to the path '/:foo.txt' is denied.
....
```

Please see [this explanation](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/2268#issuecomment-283755725) for why `${/:foo.txt} = 'hi, mom'` - whose _Windows_ equivalent is `${c:foo.txt} = 'hi, mom'` - should work.

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.0-alpha (v6.0.0-alpha.16) on Darwin Kernel Version 16.4.0: Thu Dec 22 22:53:21 PST 2016; root:xnu-3789.41.3~3/RELEASE_X86_64
```

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body:
Namespace notation does work but not when using "/:" as the drive. If you create a new drive named 'root'
`    New-PSDrive -PSProvider filesystem -root / -scope global -name root:`
Then cd into that drive
`    cd "root:$home"`
doing
`    ${root:foo.txt} = 'hi, mom'`
`    Get-Content foo.txt`
works fine. 

In fact you can't use '/:' as a drive anywhere. For example, `resolve-path /:` fails with path not found whereas `resolve-path root:` works fine. This appears to be the real issue - that you can't use '/' as a drive name in paths.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
The FileSystem provider explicitly disallows it:

```powershell
PS /home/steve> New-PSDrive -Root / -PSProvider FileSystem -Name /:                
New-PSDrive : Cannot process the drive name because the drive name contains one 
or more of the following characters that are not valid: ; ~ / \ . :
At line:1 char:1
+ New-PSDrive -Root / -PSProvider FileSystem -Name /:
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [New-PSDrive], PSArgumentExcep 
   tion
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Argument,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.NewPSDriveCo 
   mmand
```

Should we support this?  Perhaps the solution is to simply have root: defined as / on Linux systems.

comments.author: msftrncs
comments.body: Still doesn't work as of 6.2.   Is the '/' drive merely a requirement internal to powershell so that it lists the filesystem provider in the drives list?  While I understand that this would be a weird concept to Linux people to use something like `dir /:.`, the fact it is listed (by `get-psdrive`) would make me think it should at least work, even though its not needed in that example.

title: Namespace variable notation referencing the FileSystem provider is broken on Unix platforms
